item.title: Canada Updates: Police Identify Suspect in Mass Shooting
item.description: The 18-year-old fatally shot her mother and stepbrother as well as six people at a school, before killing herself. Her motive was unclear, but police had visited her home several times for mental health issues.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Eagle Vision Agency/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Iran Commemorates Revolution, With U.S. Warships Lurking Off the Coast
item.description: The authoritarian clerical regime in Tehran came to power in 1979. Today, it presides over a country that is deeply polarized and under threat of an American attack.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A gathering near Azadi Tower in Tehran on Wednesday, the anniversary of the 1979 Islamic Revolution, which overthrew the shah.

item.title: Revelations in Epstein Files Lead to Resignations and Investigations Around the World
item.description: Disclosures in documents released by the Trump administration have roiled the world, leading to resignations and the threat of legal charges far beyond American borders.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Uma Sanghvi/The Palm Beach Post, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Jeffrey Epstein in court in West Palm Beach, Fla., in 2008.

item.title: The Bangladesh Elections Are on Thursday. Here’s What to Know.
item.description: Bangladesh is holding national elections for the first time since 2024, when a student movement ousted the prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das and Saif Hasnat
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dhaka, the capital of Bangladesh, is preparing to hold elections on Thursday.

item.title: How Hate Groups Are Using Online Games to Recruit Kids
item.description: Fringe movements are using games and other online platforms to draw growing numbers of children to their causes, new data and dozens of interviews show.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.category: Global Project Against Hate and Extremism
item.media:description: Extremists are now using video games like Roblox to recruit new followers.

item.title: NATO Is Expected to Step Up Arctic Security. Here’s Why.
item.description: As Russia displays its military might in the Arctic region, the Western alliance is beginning a mission to increase its presence there.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: A Danish navy vessel patrolling the waters off Nuuk, Greenland, in March.

item.title: U.K. Police Weigh Whether to Formally Investigate Former Prince Andrew Over Epstein Accusations
item.description: The police are weighing whether to formally investigate Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor over accusations he shared confidential information with Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, the former prince, at a funeral in London in September.

item.title: Away From Pomp of Olympics, Homeless Shiver on Streets of Milan
item.description: Six homeless people have died in the Italian city in recent weeks, highlighting the widening inequality as the Games unfold there.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Josephine de La Bruyère
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers helping a homeless person at the Garibaldi station in Milan on Sunday.

item.title: Hong Kong Activist Anna Kwok’s Father Convicted of National Security Crime
item.description: In her first interview about her father, the exiled Hong Kong activist Anna Kwok said the authorities were targeting her family to try to silence her.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Anna Kwok testifying during a hearing on Capitol Hill in Washington, D.C., in 2023.

item.title: ‘Finding Harmony’ Documentary on King Charles Shows His Longtime Concern for Environment
item.description: Environmentalism may have gone out of fashion on Wall Street and in the White House, but the British monarch says he remains deeply committed to the cause in a new documentary, ‘Finding Harmony’.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Tim Graham Photo Library, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Prince Charles in his garden at Highgrove, southwestern England, in 1986. After he said he talked to his plants, he was widely mocked in the British news media.

item.title: Russia Nears Capture of Key Ukrainian Towns After Year of Grinding Assaults
item.description: Russian troops have advanced at a glacial pace in recent months, but gains in southern and eastern Ukraine could give Moscow an edge in U.S.-mediated peace talks.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.category: Center for Strategic and International Studies

item.title: Trump’s Threats to Cuba’s Oil Suppliers Put Mexico in a Bind
item.description: The longstanding alliance between Cuba and Mexico is under mounting pressure from the United States, forcing President Claudia Sheinbaum into a precarious balancing act.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Claudia Sheinbaum of Mexico now must juggle two competing priorities: honoring long‑standing ties to Havana while navigating an essential but increasingly strained relationship with Washington.

item.title: Hamas Would Keep Some Weapons Initially in Draft Gaza Plan
item.description: Israel is unlikely to withdraw its troops from the enclave before Hamas and other militant groups lay down their arms.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon, Natan Odenheimer and Abu Bakr Bashir
item.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Armed Hamas militants searching for the body of an Israeli hostage near Gaza City in November.

item.title: What to Know About Canada’s New Bridge to the U.S. That Trump Hates
item.description: President Trump’s threat to block the opening of the new crossing is the latest in a long string of challenges for the project.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai and Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Gordie Howe International Bridge, which is expected to open this year, will connect Windsor, Ontario, and Detroit.

item.title: Olympic Figure Skaters Are on Thin Ice Over Music Copyright Rules
item.description: Several athletes have found themselves caught up in controversies over musical choices before and during one of the biggest competitions of their careers.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:description: The Canadian ice dancing pair Zachary Lagha and Marjorie Lajoie performing on Saturday in Milan.

item.title: Turkish Nobel Novelist Orhan Pamuk Gets the Netflix Series He Wanted
item.description: After publishing more than 20 books and winning a Nobel Prize, the Turkish author fought to bring a celebrated novel to the screen — on his own terms.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Emin Ozmen
item.media:description: Orhan Pamuk in his office in Istanbul, in an apartment building named for his family.

item.title: Bangladesh Holds First Elections After 2024 Student Protests
item.description: At the vanguard of Gen Z movements, protesters in Bangladesh ousted the prime minister in 2024. They now face the hard reality of winning change through elections.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das, Saif Hasnat and Lam Yik Fei
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times

item.title: Top U.S. Energy Official Presses Venezuela to Do More to Spur Investment
item.description: Energy Secretary Chris Wright is one of the highest ranking American officials to visit Venezuela in nearly 30 years, marking warmer ties between Washington and Caracas.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amuay refinery, Venezuela’s largest, in Punto Fijo, Falcón state.

item.title: Mexico May Be on Brink of Losing Its Measles-Free Status
item.description: The country’s confirmed cases have topped 9,000 since last year, raising fears that a high-stakes evaluation in April could lead to its status being revoked.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:description: A health worker administering a dose of the measles vaccine in Mexico City last week. “We are confident that the outbreak will be controlled,” President Claudia Sheinbaum said on Wednesday.

item.title: In Tumbler Ridge, a community in stunned agony.
item.description: Residents embraced and wiped away tears a day after one of the worst mass shootings in the history of Canada rocked the small, remote town.
item.dc:creator: Sara Harowitz
item.media:description: The secondary school in Tumbler Ridge, British Columbia, that was the scene of a mass shooting, on Wednesday.

item.title: Takaichi’s New Superpowers
item.description: Japan’s voters just gave their prime minister a huge mandate to transform her country. What comes next?
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:description: Sanae Takaichi’s party won a supermajority in elections on Sunday.

item.title: Switzerland to Vote on Capping Population at 10 Million
item.description: After a campaign by a right-wing opposition party, the government will hold a referendum in June that would require measures to limit immigration.
item.dc:creator: Tatiana Firsova
item.media:description: A man walking with two children in Zurich. Switzerland will vote in June on a proposal to cap its population at 10 million through 2050.

item.title: Jordan Stolz Sets Olympic Record in Speedskating
item.description: Stolz put an end to Dutch dominance in the men’s sport, cruising to his first Olympic gold medal.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather and Doug Mills

item.title: U.K. Inquest Finds British Woman Was Killed ‘Unlawfully’ in Texas Shooting
item.description: A British coroner ruled that a Texas man acted with gross negligence when he accidentally shot his 23-year-old daughter, who was visiting from Britain last year.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross and Christine Hauser

item.title: Epstein Files Include Grainy Videos From Inside His Florida Home
item.description: The clips from Jeffrey Epstein’s home office appear to show him with young women.
item.dc:creator: Jane Bradley and David Enrich
item.media:description: A still from a grainy black-and-white video showed Jeffrey Epstein’s home office in Florida.

item.title: Why Iran’s Nuclear Program Isn’t the Only Threat
item.description: While talks with Iran have focused on its nuclear program, Israel’s greater immediate concern is Iran’s rebuilding of its ability to launch missiles at Israel, as it did during last year’s war. Our national security reporter Mark Mazzetti breaks down the latest intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti, Coleman Lowndes, Christina Shaman, James Surdam, Jon Hazell, Rafaela Balster and Samuel Granados

item.title: What Questions Do You Have About Saudi Arabia?
item.description: “Ask a Correspondent” will take your questions to Vivian Nereim, our Gulf bureau chief.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Vjosa Isai

item.title: Tumbler Ridge Shooting: What to Know About the Victims and Suspect
item.description: Police identified the suspect of a shooting in Tumbler Ridge, British Columbia that has shocked a country where such acts of violence are rare.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Vjosa Isai and Ravi Mattu
item.media:credit: Alana Paterson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tumbler Ridge Secondary School on Wednesday.

item.title: 9 Killed and 25 Injured in Shootings in Tumbler Ridge, Canada
item.description: The police said the suspect died of a self-inflicted injury after the shooting in Tumbler Ridge, a remote community in British Columbia.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado, Vjosa Isai and Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: A screenshot from a video showing the school building where a shooting took place in Tumbler Ridge, British Columbia, on Tuesday.

item.title: ‘I will know every victim,’ says mayor of close-knit Tumbler Ridge.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: A video grab handout showing students exiting a school in Tumbler Ridge Secondary School in British Columbia, Canada, following the shooting on Tuesday.

item.title: Students and Teachers Hid in School for Hours During British Columbia Shooting
item.description: The shooting in Tumbler Ridge was one of the deadliest in Canada’s history. Seven people, including the suspected shooter, were found dead at the local secondary school.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado

item.title: Canada Launched Major Gun Reforms in 2020 After Its Deadliest Mass Shooting
item.description: The country’s deadliest mass shooting, in Nova Scotia, led to the creation of a comprehensive program after 23 people died, including the attacker.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: A makeshift memorial in Portapique, Nova Scotia, for the victims of Canada’s deadliest mass shooting in 2020.

item.title: A Peaceful Mountain Town in Western Canada Is Shaken by Deadly Shooting
item.description: Tumbler Ridge sits at the foothills of the Rocky Mountains in northeastern British Columbia, and is surrounded by expansive mountain ranges and a geological park.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai and Yan Zhuang

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.description: The tenth person who was found
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado, Vjosa Isai and Yan Zhuang

item.title: Guatemala to End Use of Cuban Doctors, Under U.S. Pressure
item.description: The program, nearly 30 years old, had allowed Cuban medical workers to fill critical needs in Guatemala, while reaping income for Cuba.
item.dc:creator: Jody García and James Wagner
item.media:description: A Cuban doctor and a patient in San Mateo, Guatemala, in 2009. Cuba’s medical brigade of health care workers has been a fixture in Guatemala for nearly 30 years.

item.title: Mexican Cartel’s Seized Ammunition Is Traced to U.S. Army Plant
item.description: About 137,000 .50-caliber rounds have been seized since 2012, and of those, 47 percent came from a plant in Kansas City, Mo., Mexico’s defense secretary said.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Marian Carrasquero for The New York Times
item.media:description: A police officer in Villa Unión, Mexico, with a .50-caliber cartridge. Mexico’s defense secretary said that about 137,000 .50-caliber rounds had been seized since 2012.

item.title: Before Trump Blasted U.S.-Canada Bridge, Owner of Competing Span Lobbied Administration
item.description: A Detroit billionaire met with Howard Lutnick, the commerce secretary, hours before President Trump said he would block the opening of a new bridge connecting Detroit to Canada, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.category: Gordie Howe International Bridge (Detroit, Mich and Windsor, Ontario)
item.media:description: President Trump said on Monday he would block the opening of the Gordie Howe International Bridge, currently under construction to link Detroit with Windsor, Ontario.

item.title: Bulgaria Is at the Heart of Europe’s Harsh New Approach to Immigration
item.description: This former military barracks in Bulgaria has become a symbol of the E.U.’s increasingly strict policing of its borders — and of what may come next.
item.dc:creator: Caitlin L. Chandler
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Russia Further Restricts Telegram, Escalating Internet Clampdown
item.description: The throttling of the communication app, used by more than 100 million Russians, endangers what remains of the country’s free internet.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne and Oleg Matsnev
item.category: Roskomnadzor (Federal Service for Supervision of Communications, Information Technology and Mass Media) (Russia)
item.media:description: The Telegram app is an enormously popular tool in Russia for news, entertainment, messaging and calling.

item.title: A Crucial Step in Trump’s Gaza Plan
item.description: Persuading Hamas to give up its weapons is the “linchpin of everything” in the president’s plan.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hamas fighters in Gaza City in November.

item.title: Sweden’s last stone topples U.S. in curling.
item.description: Sweden’s sibling team took advantage of the hammer to edge the Americans in the final end.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather and James Hill
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times

item.title: The Ties That Bound the UK’s ‘Prince of Darkness’ Peter Mandelson to Jeffrey Epstein
item.description: For years Peter Mandelson, a senior British politician, concealed the depth of his friendship with the convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, until new files were released.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Jane Bradley
item.media:description: Peter Mandelson, then Britain’s ambassador to the U.S., in Washington last year.

item.title: Italy’s Top Sports Journalists Plan to Strike Over Anchor’s Olympics Gaffes
item.description: Paolo Petrecca made numerous gaffes while commentating on the Olympics opening ceremonies for Italy’s public broadcaster. Journalists are incensed.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:description: Mariah Carey performing at one of the opening ceremonies for the 2026 Milan-Cortina Winter Olympics on Friday.

item.title: Israelis Protest Surge in Gun Crime Within Arab Community
item.description: Palestinian and Jewish citizens of Israel joined forces to demand government action in the face of a spiraling death toll from criminal violence among Arabs.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner and Rawan Sheikh Ahmad
item.media:description: Protesters calling for greater security amid rising crime in their communities in Tel Aviv on Tuesday.

item.title: Olympic Officials Ban Ukrainian’s Helmet Honoring War Dead
item.description: Vladyslav Heraskevych said he would risk disqualification to wear a helmet that the International Olympic Committee said defied a ban on political speech.
item.dc:creator: Heather Knight
item.media:description: Vladyslav Heraskevych, a Ukrainian athlete, at a skeleton training session in Cortina d’Ampezzo on Monday. His helmet features images of countrymen who were killed in the war with Russia.

item.title: Chappell Roan Leaves Casey Wasserman Agency Over Epstein Files
item.description: Casey Wasserman, who founded and leads the talent agency bearing his name, exchanged flirtatious emails with Ghislaine Maxwell in the early 2000s.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Chappell Roan at the 2026 Grammy Awards.

item.title: An Olympian Quest in Milan: Glimpsing a K-Pop Superstar
item.description: Celebrities abound at the Winter Games. For fans, seeing one up close can be its own grueling competition.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Keh
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rotating cast of fans has gathered outside a Milan hotel since last week to see Sunghoon, a K-pop star visiting for the Olympic Games.

item.title: How the Israeli President’s Visit to Australia Created a ‘Tinder Box’
item.description: Isaac Herzog’s trip led to widespread rallies and tested the restrictions on protests that Australia installed after a deadly attack on a Jewish celebration.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police clashing with protesters opposed to the visit of President Isaac Herzog of Israel to Sydney on Monday.

item.title: Russia Knocked Out the Heat. So She Slept in a Tent on Her Bed.
item.description: With defiant ingenuity, Kyiv residents are trying to find ways to stay warm in a cruel winter.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Lynsey Addario
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Svitlana Zinovieva sits in the tent she and her daughter, Oleksandra Buzko, have mounted above the bed to stay warm at home amid subzero temperatures in Kyiv, last month.

item.title: How Ukrainians Are Coping Without Heat
item.description: Our Kyiv bureau chief, Andrew E. Kramer, describes how Kyiv residents are coping with Russia’s unrelenting assaults on their country’s heating and electrical systems and finding ways to stay warm in a cruel winter.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Lynsey Addario and Rebecca Suner

item.title: Eating Kosher in the Heart of Syria: Lamb-Stuffed Zucchini but Hold the Yogurt
item.description: In the post-Assad era, more Jews are visiting a country that some fled decades ago. One hotel restaurant offers a corner where religious dietary requirements are melded with the local cuisine.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Alice Martins for The New York Times
item.media:description: Inspecting kosher appetizers ready to be served in Damascus, the Syrian capital, in January.

item.title: Nicaragua Blocks a Route from Cuba to the U.S.
item.description: The Trump administration has criticized Nicaragua for serving as an illegal immigration pathway to the United States.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:description: Cubans lining up outside the Nicaraguan Embassy in Havana on Monday, after Nicaragua ended visa-free entry for Cuban citizens.

item.title: A Shift in Chinese Taste for Durian Throws Malaysian Farmers Into Turmoil
item.description: Malaysian durian farmers saw immense profits over the last decade as China snapped up their produce. But tastes have shifted.
item.dc:creator: Zunaira Saieed and Lauren DeCicca
item.media:credit: Lauren DeCicca for The New York Times

item.title: How Italy’s Police and Army Compete to Enlist Italian Olympians
item.description: Most Italian athletes at the Winter Games subsidize their training by joining the police or the military, which vie to enlist the best talent.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Italian curler Amos Mosaner.

item.title: Air Canada and WestJet Cancel Flights to Cuba Over Jet Fuel Shortage
item.description: The Trump administration’s crackdown on oil shipments to Cuba is beginning to wreak havoc on the Caribbean island’s travel industry.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:credit: Darryl Dyck/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Air Canada planes at Vancouver International Airport. The airline announced on Monday that it had suspended its 16 flights per week to four Cuban cities. Canada is the top source of tourists to Cuba.

item.title: Starmer’s Epstein Crisis
item.description: Among the powerful men facing fallout from the files, the one in deepest trouble appears to have never met Epstein: the British prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer is facing calls to resign over the Epstein scandal.
